text: Monocyte arrest and transmigration on inflamed endothelium in shear flow is inhibited by adenovirus - mediated gene transfer of <extra_id_0> IkappaB-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: Mobilization of nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) activates transcription of genes encoding endothelial adhesion molecules and chemokines that contribute to monocyte infiltration critical in atherogenesis .

Inhibition of NF-kappaB has been achieved by pharmacological and genetic approaches ; however , monocyte interactions with activated endothelium in shear flow following gene transfer of the NF-kappaB inhibitor <extra_id_0> IkappaB-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> have not been studied .

text: Adhesion assays under physiological shear flow conditions showed that firm arrest , spreading , and transmigration of monocytes on <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - activated endothelium was markedly inhibited by <extra_id_0> IkappaB-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> overexpression .

text: Inhibition with monoclonal antibodies and peptide antagonists inferred that this was due to reduced expression of Ig integrin ligand as well as of chemokines specifically involved in these events .

In contrast , rolling of monocytes was increased by <extra_id_0> IkappaB-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transfer and was partly mediated by <extra_id_0> P-selectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ; however , it appeared to be unaffected by the inhibition of <extra_id_0> E-selectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction .

text: Thus , our data provide novel evidence that selective modulation of NF-kappaB by adenoviral transfer of <extra_id_0> IkappaB-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> impairs the expression of multiple endothelial gene products required for subsequent monocyte arrest and emigration in shear flow and thus for monocyte infiltration in atherosclerotic plaques .
